title: 115_s1777
content: The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes an excise tax on corporations with low-wage employees under a new chapter in the Internal Revenue Code. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers who employ low-wage employees based on the aggregate amount of wages paid during the calendar year. The term "applicable employer" is defined as an employer required to make tax deposits under specific chapters for more than 180 days in the preceding year. The "Corporate Responsibility Fee Act of 2017" imposes a tax on applicable employers who employ low-wage employees based on the aggregate amount of wages paid during the calendar year. The term "applicable employer" excludes Federal or governmental entities, churches, or qualified church organizations. Aggregation rules from section 414 apply, with a substitution of 'more than 50 percent' for 'more than 80 percent'. The term 'low-wage employee' is defined. The term 'low-wage employee' is defined as an employee who receives wages less than 218 percent of the Federal poverty line. Rules similar to section 36B(d)(3)(B) apply. The applicable percentage for determining the reduction in the amount described in subparagraph (A) is calculated based on the number of weeks the individual was not an employee of the applicable employer during the calendar year. The applicable employee ratio determines the percentage of reduction in the amount based on the number of weeks the individual was not an employee of the applicable employer during the calendar year. The applicable percentages are as follows: 25% for 25% or less, 50% for greater than 25% but not greater than 50%, 75% for greater than 50% but not greater than 75%, and 100% for greater than 75%. The low-wage employee ratio is calculated as the percentage of low-wage employees to total employees for an employer. A health and retirement offset reduces the applicable percentage by 25 points for qualifying employers. The applicable percentage for qualifying employers is reduced by 25 percentage points if they offer minimum essential coverage to all full-time low-wage employees and their families under an eligible employer-sponsored health plan. The plan must cover at least 60 percent of benefits costs and the employee's contribution cannot exceed a certain percentage of their annual wages. The plan must also meet retirement plan requirements for low-wage employees. The applicable percentage is determined by section 36B(c)(2)(B)(II) for the plan year. The retirement plan must meet requirements for low-wage employees, with the applicable percentage determined by section 36B(c)(2)(B)(II) for the plan year. Eligible employees can participate in applicable eligible retirement plans maintained by the employer. The term `applicable eligible retirement plan' refers to a defined contribution plan requiring employer contributions of at least 5% of the employee's compensation or a defined benefit plan ensuring a minimum annual retirement benefit based on years of service. The term 'applicable eligible retirement plan' refers to a defined contribution plan or a defined benefit plan meeting specific requirements related to employer contributions and retirement benefits based on years of service. The curr_chunk discusses the requirements for an employee to receive a pay credit of at least 5 percent of compensation in a retirement plan for the plan year. It also defines an eligible retirement plan as a simplified employee pension under certain conditions. The curr_chunk outlines regulations for determining final average pay in a retirement plan, allowing alternative plan designs, and requiring plans to meet requirements without considering social security contributions. The curr_chunk specifies exclusions for certain employees in retirement plans based on age and years of service, following regulations for plan requirements without considering social security contributions. The curr_chunk outlines exclusions for employees in retirement plans based on collective bargaining agreements, good faith bargaining, and nonresident aliens working outside the United States. The curr_chunk provides definitions for "wages" and rules for tax allocation among entities treated as a single employer. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by Chapter 37--Corporate Responsibility Tax apply to calendar years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act.
